item.title: Dog Owners Walk 22 Minutes More Per Day. And Yes, It Counts As Exercise
item.description: June 12, 2017 - A new study finds dog owners on average walk 22 more minutes more per day compared to people without dogs. The benefits of walking include a lower risk of heart disease and premature death.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 12, 2017 - A new study finds dog owners on average walk 22 more minutes more per day compared to people without dogs. The benefits of walking include a lower risk of heart disease and premature death. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/12/532625213/dog-owners-walk-22-minutes-more-per-day-and-yes-it-counts-as-exercise

item.title: A Drugmaker Tries To Cash In On The Opioid Epidemic, One State Law At A Time
item.description: June 12, 2017 - The maker of one medical treatment for opioid abuse has successfully lobbied statehouses around the country to pass policies that tilt addiction treatment practices in favor of the company's drug.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 12, 2017 - The maker of one medical treatment for opioid abuse has successfully lobbied statehouses around the country to pass policies that tilt addiction treatment practices in favor of the company's drug. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/12/523774660/a-drugmaker-tries-to-cash-in-on-the-opioid-epidemic-one-state-law-at-a-time

item.title: Is Zika Still A Problem In Florida And The Caribbean?
item.description: June 12, 2017 - The Zika outbreak in Florida is officially over. And cases are dropping across the Caribbean. But doctors say the risk to pregnant women there — whether residents or travelers — isn't gone.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 12, 2017 - The Zika outbreak in Florida is officially over. And cases are dropping across the Caribbean. But doctors say the risk to pregnant women there — whether residents or travelers — isn't gone. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/12/531949066/is-zika-still-a-problem-in-florida-and-the-caribbean

item.title: A Pulse Nightclub Responder Confronts A New Crisis: PTSD
item.description: June 12, 2017 - The Pulse Nightclub shootings in Orlando a year ago killed 49 people. It was a horrific scene for first responders, and some are still struggling to cope with what they saw that night.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 12, 2017 - The Pulse Nightclub shootings in Orlando a year ago killed 49 people. It was a horrific scene for first responders, and some are still struggling to cope with what they saw that night. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/12/531751457/a-pulse-nightclub-responder-confronts-a-new-crisis-ptsd

item.title: As Popularity Of Baby Boxes Grows, Skeptics Say More Testing Is Needed
item.description: June 12, 2017 - New mom Maisha Watson uses one of the 20,000 cardboard boxes given out so far in New Jersey. She's glad to have a safe spot for her son to sleep. But some question the boxes' safety and effectiveness.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 12, 2017 - New mom Maisha Watson uses one of the 20,000 cardboard boxes given out so far in New Jersey. She's glad to have a safe spot for her son to sleep. But some question the boxes' safety and effectiveness. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/12/532132906/as-popularity-of-baby-boxes-grows-skeptics-say-more-testing-is-needed

item.title: Is Zika Dangerous For Kids? It Probably Depends On The Age
item.description: June 12, 2017 - Studies have shown that Zika can damage a fetus's brain in the third trimester. Would there also be an impact on the brain of a newborn?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 12, 2017 - Studies have shown that Zika can damage a fetus's brain in the third trimester. Would there also be an impact on the brain of a newborn? http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/06/12/532083664/is-zika-dangerous-for-kids-probably-depends-on-the-age

item.title: GOP's Proposed Cuts To Medicaid Threaten Treatment For Opioid Addiction
item.description: June 11, 2017 - Expanding Medicaid has helped many people caught up in the opioid epidemic get treatment. But doctors say the proposed Republican changes to the Affordable Care Act could jeopardize these programs.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 11, 2017 - Expanding Medicaid has helped many people caught up in the opioid epidemic get treatment. But doctors say the proposed Republican changes to the Affordable Care Act could jeopardize these programs. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/11/531214580/gops-proposed-cuts-to-medicaid-threaten-treatment-for-opioid-addiction

item.title: A Promise To Her Newborn Daughter: No More Female Genital Mutilation
item.description: June 11, 2017 - Jaha Dukureh is featured in the documentary "Jaha's Promise." She got Gambia to outlaw the practice. But could she convince her father?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 11, 2017 - Jaha Dukureh is featured in the documentary "Jaha's Promise." She got Gambia to outlaw the practice. But could she convince her father? http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/06/11/532094386/a-promise-to-her-newborn-daughter-no-more-female-genital-mutilation

item.title: Why We Should Say Someone Is A 'Person With An Addiction,' Not An Addict
item.description: June 11, 2017 - Journalists should quit calling a person who uses drugs an "addict," according to The Associated Press Stylebook. This follows a trend toward "person first" descriptions of people with diseases.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 11, 2017 - Journalists should quit calling a person who uses drugs an "addict," according to The Associated Press Stylebook. This follows a trend toward "person first" descriptions of people with diseases. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/11/531931490/change-from-addict-to-person-with-an-addiction-is-long-overdue

item.title: A Dad Takes His Son To The Doctor And Discovers Fear Of Vaccines
item.description: June 10, 2017 - As a science journalist, I know vaccines are safe. But when it was time to take my son to get his shots, I suddenly found myself overwhelmed by fear. Does science stand a chance against emotion?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 10, 2017 - As a science journalist, I know vaccines are safe. But when it was time to take my son to get his shots, I suddenly found myself overwhelmed by fear. Does science stand a chance against emotion? http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/10/532110787/a-dad-takes-his-son-to-the-doctor-and-discovers-fear-of-vaccines

item.title: FDA Asks Drug Maker To Pull Opioid Opana ER Off The Market
item.description: June 9, 2017 - The Food and Drug Administration requested drug maker Endo Pharmaceuticals stop selling Opana ER, which is an opioid. NPR's Robert Siegel speaks with Dr. Janet Woodcock, director of the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, about the decision.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 9, 2017 - The Food and Drug Administration requested drug maker Endo Pharmaceuticals stop selling Opana ER, which is an opioid. NPR's Robert Siegel speaks with Dr. Janet Woodcock, director of the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, about the decision. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/09/532289054/fda-asks-drug-maker-to-pull-opioid-opana-er-off-the-market

item.title: Got Cancer Questions? This Little-Known Hotline Is Here To Help
item.description: June 9, 2017 - For 40 years, people have been able to call a service funded by the National Cancer Institute to get information about cancer treatments. Doctors say it's still useful even in the age of Twitter.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 9, 2017 - For 40 years, people have been able to call a service funded by the National Cancer Institute to get information about cancer treatments. Doctors say it's still useful even in the age of Twitter. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/09/532230703/got-cancer-questions-this-little-known-hotline-is-here-to-help

item.title: FDA Calls On Drugmaker To Pull A Powerful Opioid Off The Market
item.description: June 8, 2017 - The Food and Drug Administration says abuse of the painkiller Opana ER has fueled an outbreak of HIV, hepatitis C and a serious blood disorder, though it was reformulated to try to reduce abuse.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 8, 2017 - The Food and Drug Administration says abuse of the painkiller Opana ER has fueled an outbreak of HIV, hepatitis C and a serious blood disorder, though it was reformulated to try to reduce abuse. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/08/532126206/fda-calls-on-drugmaker-to-pull-a-powerful-opioid-off-the-market

item.title: CDC Reveals Sharper Numbers Of Zika Birth Defects From U.S. Territories
item.description: June 8, 2017 - About 5 percent of pregnant women infected with Zika in Puerto Rico and other U.S. territories last year had babies with birth defects, says the federal health agency. And the risk isn't over.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 8, 2017 - About 5 percent of pregnant women infected with Zika in Puerto Rico and other U.S. territories last year had babies with birth defects, says the federal health agency. And the risk isn't over. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/08/532087184/cdc-reveals-sharper-numbers-of-zika-birth-defects-from-u-s-territories

item.title: Aid-In-Dying Requires More Than Just A Law, Californians Find
item.description: June 8, 2017 - In the year since the state enacted a law allowing doctors to prescribe lethal drugs for terminal patients who request it, over 500 people have sought that help. But some doctors are still reluctant.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 8, 2017 - In the year since the state enacted a law allowing doctors to prescribe lethal drugs for terminal patients who request it, over 500 people have sought that help. But some doctors are still reluctant. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/08/530944807/aid-in-dying-requires-more-than-just-a-law-californians-find
